Executive Summary



The Risk Management Program (RMP) is being updated to enable Patheon API, Inc. Florence, South Carolina Plant, to satisfy the required elements of the United States Environmental Protection Agency's (USEPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) rule (40 CFR 68).  Specifically, the RMP includes the addition of anhydrous ammonia as a Program 2 chemical.  RCI is currently installing three new ammonia refrigeration systems (chillers) at the Regional Energy Center (REC).  Each chiller unit will contain approximately 5,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  



Accidental Release Prevention and ER Policies



Patheon API Inc. has implemented environmental and safety systems in order to minimize the potential release of anhydrous ammonia.  These systems include: a complete review and hazards analysis, detailed safety and environmental standards, a fully automated process control system (PLC) with built in safety interlocks, management of change program, pre-start up safety reviews and an on-going inspection and preventive maintenance program.  Prior to the start of a new chiller, all affected personnel are trained on the hazards, the safe use, storage, handling and emergency response procedures for anhydrous ammonia.



    Facility Description and the Regulated Substances Handled



Patheon API Inc. is an active pharmaceutical ingredient (API) manufacturing facility located in Florence, South Carolina.  The property is a 1,400 acre site of which approximately 120 acres have been developed for industrial use.  The developed portion is located in the center of the property, ensuring a significant buffer or distance to the property boundary.



Patheon API Inc. is installing three new ammonia refrigeration systems (chillers) at the Regional Energy Center (REC).  Each chiller unit will contain 5,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.  Each chiller will be installed in a separate bay isolated by a 2-hour rated firewall.





The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and

Chemical specific Prevention Steps



The ammonia chillers are located in the Regional Energy Center of the RCI facility.  Each chiller is located in a separate chiller bay and contains 5,000 pounds of ammonia.  In the event of an ammonia leak, the emergency ventilation system will be activated.  During this period, room ventilation will increase from approximately 2,000 CFM to 17,500 CFM and will exhaust to an ammonia scrubber.  The emergency scrubber system will remove vapors and aerosols generated from an ammonia leak.  The scrubber system consist of one packed-bed scrubber with liquid reservoir and redundent transfer pumps, exhaust fans, instrumentation and controls.  Each chiller enclosure has two alarm panels and a safety PLC.  The PLC monitors the ammonia sensors, damper limit and temperature switches.  In the event of a can ammonia release from the chiller, the ammonia gas detection begins to alarm (white light) at 15 ppm ammonia resulting in the start up of the scrubber.  At 35 ppm ammonia concentration in the bay, a second (yellow) indication light is initiated and the scrubber continues to run.  At 200 ppm ammonia concentration, an audible alarm and red indication light is activated.  At this point, the chiller is shutdown.  If the ammonia concentration in the bay reaches 9,500 ppm, power is automatically shutdown to the bay.  During this entire sequence, operating personnel continually monitor the equpment operations.  



Additional accidental release controls include the insallation of a chiller bay sump and liquid pumpout system to either a waste tank or diffusion tank.  This secondary containment ensures released ammonia is routed to a safe location.  Each chiller bay is constructed of 2 hour fire rated walls in order to minimize the impact of a potential fire within the chiller bay.  Cameras have been installed in each chiller bay and are remotly monitored by operating personnel at the REC Control Room during routine or emergency situations.

The Worst-Case Release Scenario and the Alternative Release Scenario



The new ammonia chillers are strategically located at the center of the property allowing for a considerable buffer to the property boundary.  This significantly reduces or minimizes the impact of a chemical release to the nearby community.  The hazard assessment was completed using the RMP*Comp Methodology.  



Worst Case Release Scenario 

 

The worst case release scenario for the site was evaluated following all Risk Management Program regulations as required by EPA.  The identified worst case scenario is a release of the entire contents of one chiller (5,000 pounds)over a ten minute period.  It is assumed the material is released and forms a liquid pool within the chiller bay sump.  Worst case conditions using very conservative assumptions include a wind speed of 1.5 m/sec, atmosphereic Stability Class F, no response from on-site emergency response personnel and no safety interlocks or devices.  Input of the preceding parameters into the the RMP*Comp program indicates that the ammonia would impact 0.7 miles from the release point.  See section 3 of the RMP submit report for more detailed information on this release scenario.

  

Alternative Release scenario

 

The Patheon API Inc. site is completing one alternate release scenario per 40 CFR Part 68.165(a)(2).  The alternative release scenario considered is in accordance with the guidelines provided in ?68.22 and ?68.28. The alternative scenario assumes that all 5,000 pounds of ammonia in a chiller are released, but that it is released through an installed safety relief device, an ammonia scrubber.  The scrubber design removal efficiency is 99%.  Conditions for the alternate case include a wind speed of 3.0 m/sec, atmospheric stability class D, with no response from on-site emergency response personnel.  Input of the preceding parameters into the the RMP*Comp program indicates that the ammonia would impact 0.1 miles from the releas

e point; resulting in the ammonia remaining within the RCI site boundary.  See section 3 of the RMP submit report for more detailed information on this release scenario.

     

    The 5-Year Accident History



The ammonia chiller system covered by the RMP is a new source; and thus there have been no accidental releases.  Patheon API Inc. will maintain a five year accident history for all accidental releases from the ammonia process that results in death, injury, property damage on site or offsite deaths, injuries, evacuation, shelter in place, property or enviornmental damage.



    The Emergency Response Program



Patheon API Inc. maintains a complete emergency response program and plan for all process operations and functions at the site.  The purpose of the site emergency response plan is to establish actions that would be taken in the event of an emergency condition.  The procedures outlined in the plan includes the elements outlined in 40 CFR 68.95(a)and will be followed in the event of a release of anhydrous ammonia from the RCI Site.  The Incident Command System (ICS) has been established in order to provide for the orderly and consistent leadership during an emergency situation.  All Hazardous Materials responders are trained to the technician Level as outlined in the OSHA Standard and have been trained on the properties and hazards associated with anhydrous ammonia.  In the event of an ammonia release within one of the chiller bays, a fully automated emergency relief system (ammonia scrubber) has been installed in order to mitigate a release.  During routine and emergency situations, the ammonia chillers are monitored by operating personnel on a continuous basis.  The plan also includes informing the public and local agencies responsible or responding to an accidental release.  The plan includes the location and nature of emergency health care available to employees of RCI and the public in the event of an ammonia release.



    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Patheon API Inc. believes continuous improvement of all environmental and safety systems is an essential function of manufacturing and support operations.   It has implemented the strategies as outlined in the American Chemistry Council Responsible Care Program.  The environmental and safety programs and systems are periodically reviewed in order to continually improve performance at the site.  All incidents are reported and investigated to ensure causative factors are identified and corrected.  An extensive, ongoing training program (including mandatory ammonia awareness and refresher training for all affected personnel) is in place to ensure all operating personnel are familiar with the safety and environmental systems in place for the ammonia chiller systems.
